conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on balls A and B when ball A is at its highest point.
Ball A is at the highest point and exerts no force on the rod.
The only force acting on ball A is gravity, providing necessary centripetal force.
The radius of the circular path for ball A is L.
The gravitational force acting on ball A is mg.
The centripetal force required for circular motion is mv_A^2/L.
Equating gravitational force to centripetal force gives v_A^2 = gL.
Ball B rotates with the same angular velocity as ball A.
The radius of the circular path for ball B is 2L.
The speed v_B of ball B is related to v_A by v_B = 2v_A.
At the lowest point, ball B experiences gravitational force and centripetal force.
The centripetal force required for ball B is 2mg.
The total upward force on ball B must balance gravitational force and provide centripetal force, giving F_B = 3mg.
The force exerted by ball B on the rod when ball A is at the highest point is 3mg.
